authors.name: Władysław Reymont
authors.description: Polish novelist and Nobel laureate (1924), best known for 'The Peasants.' A leading figure of the Young Poland movement, his naturalist prose depicts Polish rural and urban life with vivid psychological detail.

authors.name: Józef Ignacy Kraszewski
authors.description: The most prolific Polish novelist of the 19th century, author of over 200 novels. His historical fiction spans Polish history from prehistoric times to the contemporary era, combining romantic vision with positivist concern for factual accuracy.

authors.name: Karol Irzykowski
authors.description: Polish novelist, literary critic, and film theorist. A pioneering modernist whose experimental novel 'Pałuba' anticipated techniques of the European avant-garde with its metafictional structure and psychological analysis.

authors.name: Stefan Żeromski
authors.description: One of the most important Polish novelists and dramatists, called 'the conscience of Polish literature.' His works explore social injustice, patriotism, and moral dilemmas with intense psychological realism.

authors.name: Eliza Orzeszkowa
authors.description: Leading Polish positivist novelist and social activist, nominated for the Nobel Prize in Literature. Her works champion social reform, depicting the lives of peasants, Jews, and the gentry in the former Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.

texts.title: Ferments (Fermenty)
texts.description: A naturalist novel depicting the moral and social 'fermentation' of a young woman from the provincial intelligentsia who seeks meaning and independence in late 19th-century Polish society. The second part of Reymont's urban tetralogy.

texts.title: An Ancient Tale (Stara baśń)
texts.description: A historical novel set in pre-Christian Poland during the legendary reign of Piast the Wheelwright. Depicts the struggle between Slavic paganism and emerging Christianity, tribal politics, and the origins of the Polish nation.

texts.title: The Hag (Pałuba)
texts.description: A pioneering modernist and metafictional novel that deconstructs the conventions of psychological realism. Through its self-aware narrator and fragmented structure, it examines the impossibility of truly knowing another person and the deceptions inherent in literary representation.

texts.title: Sisyphean Labors (Syzyfowe prace)
texts.description: A novel about the Russification of Polish youth in a gymnasium in the Russian partition of Poland. Follows the awakening of national consciousness among students subjected to systematic cultural suppression, culminating in an act of collective defiance.

texts.title: The Dziurdzia Family (Dziurdziowie)
texts.description: A rural novel depicting the life of a peasant family in the former Polish-Lithuanian borderlands. Explores themes of poverty, superstition, family bonds, and the clash between traditional village life and modernity.

texts.title: The Wellborn (Bene nati)
texts.description: A rural novel examining the decaying petty nobility (szlachta) and their relationship with the peasantry. The Latin title ('wellborn') ironically underscores the contrast between noble pretensions and actual moral worth.
